story:
Welcome to Uber Hates Tips

Uber Hates Tips is a simple way for you to tip your Uber driver anonymously using your phone. Your driver will know you tipped, but never how much you tipped. Did we mention it's free?

Uber and tips. The saga.

If you're an Uber driver, you know that this has been a problem from day one. Uber told everyone that tips were included in the Uber fare -- even though they weren't -- and you risked getting "deactivated" if you even discussed tipping with your passengers.

If you're an Uber passenger, you believed Uber when they told you that tips were included. And then your Uber rating began sinking and you found it harder and harder to get rides. "What did I do?," you thought. "I never make my driver wait. I'm pleasant and cheerful. I take regular showers. Why did my driver down-rate me?"

Now you know that it isn't that your driver down-rated you for being a bad passenger. It's that your driver up-rated other passengers to thank them for tipping. So by trying to remove tipping from the equation, Uber has managed to make it even more uncomfortable for everyone concerned.

But Uber hates tips. Why is this OK now?

Because of a recent court case, Uber has agreed to a settlement that will allow Uber drivers to accept tips from passengers and even put signs in their cars reminding passengers that tips are appreciated. (We should note here that the court case itself still has a little way to go before the settlement becomes final.)

So it looks like Uber drivers can now expect to earn tips like everyone else. This solves a problem -- sort of, Uber still refuses to put a tip line in its app -- for you Uber drivers but it just creates one for passengers. Passengers regularly say that one of the things they liked best about Uber was not having to worry about tipping. Surveys show that this is not because they are cheap, but because they do not want to stress about being judged on their tips. They also show that many Uber passengers hate tipping in cash because they often carry only credit cards and their phone. This goes double for business passengers who are happy to tip but need receipts so they can be reimbursed.

We at Uber Hates Tips feel everyone's pain, which is why we worked out a solution: a simple way for people to tip their drivers anonymously using their phones. When someone tips, the driver will immediately get a message on her phone letting her know that she's gotten a tip but not for how much or from whom. We think this is the best of both worlds. The driver gets a tip. The passenger gets a big smile and a "Thank you!". And, best of all, nobody gets any stress.

How does it work?

As simply as we could make it. Uber drivers will have a sign with a QR code on it in their cars. Each QR code is unique to that driver. The app scans the QR code, you enter the amount you want to tip in the little box and press send. That's all you have to do.

Of course, that's only the beginning of the process. The driver still has to react with happy surprise when he sees that a Good Friend has sent him a tip and then thank you profusely, not only for tipping, but for helping build the system that made his tip possible. So there is a little work involved.

How will drivers get their QR codes?

When they sign up for their account -- signing up is free, of course -- the system will generate a unique QR code for them that they can download as a pdf and then print out or display on a tablet in their cars.

What is this about custom titles?

If you contribute $10 or more to this campaign, you'll receive a special title that will be included in the message sent to your driver when you tip. This will let the driver know that you aren't just a passenger, you're one of the handful of truly special people that made it possible for him to earn a decent living and put kale on the table. Children will be named after you. Though why someone would want to name their child "BFF" is a mystery to us.

Will people have to have the app to use it?

Sounds like a trick question, doesn't it? You will be surprised to learn that the answer is "No." If your driver has a sign in his car with his personal QR code on it, you will still be able to use it to tip your driver, even if you don't have the app.

If you don't have the app and you scan the driver's sign, you will be taken to a special form linked specifically to that driver that will allow you to enter your credit card information and a tip. You'll also be encouraged to download the app because, really, why would you want to do that twice? Wouldn't it be much better just to enter a tip and push send?

Is this going to be safe and secure?

Absolutely. We are not actually touching your credit card information or the driver's banking information ourselves. All of that is stored with Braintree, who will also be doing all the financial processing.

So what, exactly, are you funding with this campaign?

The first 20K, our funding target, will allow us to create a very basic Android app and a simple back-end that will allow drivers to register and get their unique QR codes. If we raise additional funds through this campaign, we have a long list of additions and improvements we will be making.

Our first priority will be an iPhone version of the app, which will cost another 20K. We very much hope the community will be excited enough about this project to help us reach this goal since that will allow our solution to reach more than 98% of Uber passengers.

After creating an iPhone app, there are a number of improvements and features that could and should be added to make the app and the back-end more functional and user friendly. These include allowing drivers to generate customizable physical signs that display their QR code and that can then be shipped to them for use in their cars, an improved user interface that will allow percentage tipping, card scanning, automatic fare calculation and a host of other features.

Some of these stretch goals would not be implemented in Version 1.0. Rather, they would be included in updates. Our primary goal is to get a stable, functional tool in the hands of Uber passengers they can use to tip their drivers. The bells and whistles will catch up soon enough but they can't be allowed to delay the project.

Does this cost anything?

We made it as free as we possibly could. First, it's 100% free to download. It's 100% free to sign up, both for drivers and for passengers. It's 100% free for drivers to download their personal QR code.

When drivers actually receive tips on the system, there is going to be a small amount deducted from each tip. These are mostly fees charged by Braintree. Initially, 4.95% + $0.30 will need to be deducted from each tip that a driver receives.

But here's the interesting part. If we can process a certain amount of tips through this system every month, we can negotiate a lower processing fee with Braintree. The more money we are able to process, the lower the fees. So if the community pulls together and makes this work, i.e., if drivers put small signs with their QR codes in their cars, we can drive these charges down for everyone. This really is a community effort.

Are you really going to call this app Uber Hates Tips?

We'd like to, but, to be honest, probably not. We've got some more normal ideas for a name but if you think you've got a good one, please suggest it. We'd have a contest to name the app, but we know you'd all vote for Appy McAppface and we're not going there.

Risks and Challenges

Technically, there aren't any serious risks or challenges at all. All the functions we are implementing are straightforward. We are using Braintree for all the financial transactions as well as for secure storage of all sensitive financial information. We have already identified a design team to handle the actual coding.

To be honest, the only real risk in this project is, well, you. Not you personally, of course, we mean the community of Uber passengers and drivers. If the community wants this to work, it will absolutely work. But we all have to do our part by downloading the app -- which will be free, of course -- and, if you're a driver, by displaying your QR code in your car.

How Can I help?

First, of course, contribute! This is really a group effort.

But more importantly, participate! If you are a driver, sign up and put your QR code in your car. Get other drivers to put their QR code in their cars, too. Tell people about this campaign. Tweet about it. Write about it on Facebook. Tell your friends. This is basically free money, people! Your friends are gonna be mad at you if you don't tell them about it!

If you are a passenger, download the app. Tell your friends, too. When you take an Uber, be sure and brag to your friends that you know all about the sign in the car and that you were one of the people who helped create it.

Oh, and there is one other thing you can do: Follow us on Twitter!


Campaign Update: Great News!

Our campaign has generated a lot of interest in some very interesting places!

As we now have actual investors excited to back our project, it will no longer be necessary to rely on crowd funding to make this project a reality. After discussing it, we all feel that the right thing to do is to put all of our contributors first, thank them for their support and refund their contributions.

BUT

We will still be providing our contributors with the perks they were promised as our way of thanking them for standing in our corner. You all believe in this as much as we do and that means a lot to us.

So watch for the public rollout of the app which should be sometime in the next 90 days . . . and you can still say, "I did that!" because you did. None of this would have been possible without your enthusiasm and support

Thanks Again!

The Uber Hates Tips Team
story_txt:
Welcome to Uber Hates Tips
Uber Hates Tips is a simple way for you to tip your Uber driver anonymously using your phone. Your driver will know you tipped, but never how much you tipped. Did we mention it's free?

Uber and tips. The saga.
If you're an Uber driver, you know that this has been a problem from day one. Uber told everyone that tips were included in the Uber fare -- even though they weren't -- and you risked getting "deactivated" if you even discussed tipping with your passengers.
If you're an Uber passenger, you believed Uber when they told you that tips were included. And then your Uber rating began sinking and you found it harder and harder to get rides. "What did I do?," you thought. "I never make my driver wait. I'm pleasant and cheerful. I take regular showers. Why did my driver down-rate me?"
Now you know that it isn't that your driver down-rated you for being a bad passenger. It's that your driver up-rated other passengers to thank them for tipping. So by trying to remove tipping from the equation, Uber has managed to make it even more uncomfortable for everyone concerned.

But Uber hates tips. Why is this OK now?

Because of a recent court case, Uber has agreed to a settlement that will allow Uber drivers to accept tips from passengers and even put signs in their cars reminding passengers that tips are appreciated. (We should note here that the court case itself still has a little way to go before the settlement becomes final.)
So it looks like Uber drivers can now expect to earn tips like everyone else. This solves a problem -- sort of, Uber still refuses to put a tip line in its app -- for you Uber drivers but it just creates one for passengers. Passengers regularly say that one of the things they liked best about Uber was not having to worry about tipping. Surveys show that this is not because they are cheap, but because they do not want to stress about being judged on their tips. They also show that many Uber passengers hate tipping in cash because they often carry only credit cards and their phone. This goes double for business passengers who are happy to tip but need receipts so they can be reimbursed.
We at Uber Hates Tips feel everyone's pain, which is why we worked out a solution: a simple way for people to tip their drivers anonymously using their phones. When someone tips, the driver will immediately get a message on her phone letting her know that she's gotten a tip but not for how much or from whom. We think this is the best of both worlds. The driver gets a tip. The passenger gets a big smile and a "Thank you!". And, best of all, nobody gets any stress.

How does it work?

As simply as we could make it. Uber drivers will have a sign with a QR code on it in their cars. Each QR code is unique to that driver. The app scans the QR code, you enter the amount you want to tip in the little box and press send. That's all you have to do.
Of course, that's only the beginning of the process. The driver still has to react with happy surprise when he sees that a Good Friend has sent him a tip and then thank you profusely, not only for tipping, but for helping build the system that made his tip possible. So there is a little work involved.

How will drivers get their QR codes?

When they sign up for their account -- signing up is free, of course -- the system will generate a unique QR code for them that they can download as a pdf and then print out or display on a tablet in their cars.

What is this about custom titles?

If you contribute $10 or more to this campaign, you'll receive a special title that will be included in the message sent to your driver when you tip. This will let the driver know that you aren't just a passenger, you're one of the handful of truly special people that made it possible for him to earn a decent living and put kale on the table. Children will be named after you. Though why someone would want to name their child "BFF" is a mystery to us.

Will people have to have the app to use it?

Sounds like a trick question, doesn't it? You will be surprised to learn that the answer is "No." If your driver has a sign in his car with his personal QR code on it, you will still be able to use it to tip your driver, even if you don't have the app.
If you don't have the app and you scan the driver's sign, you will be taken to a special form linked specifically to that driver that will allow you to enter your credit card information and a tip. You'll also be encouraged to download the app because, really, why would you want to do that twice? Wouldn't it be much better just to enter a tip and push send?

Is this going to be safe and secure?

Absolutely. We are not actually touching your credit card information or the driver's banking information ourselves. All of that is stored with Braintree, who will also be doing all the financial processing.
So what, exactly, are you funding with this campaign?
The first 20K, our funding target, will allow us to create a very basic Android app and a simple back-end that will allow drivers to register and get their unique QR codes. If we raise additional funds through this campaign, we have a long list of additions and improvements we will be making.
Our first priority will be an iPhone version of the app, which will cost another 20K. We very much hope the community will be excited enough about this project to help us reach this goal since that will allow our solution to reach more than 98% of Uber passengers.
After creating an iPhone app, there are a number of improvements and features that could and should be added to make the app and the back-end more functional and user friendly. These include allowing drivers to generate customizable physical signs that display their QR code and that can then be shipped to them for use in their cars, an improved user interface that will allow percentage tipping, card scanning, automatic fare calculation and a host of other features.
Some of these stretch goals would not be implemented in Version 1.0. Rather, they would be included in updates. Our primary goal is to get a stable, functional tool in the hands of Uber passengers they can use to tip their drivers. The bells and whistles will catch up soon enough but they can't be allowed to delay the project.

Does this cost anything?

We made it as free as we possibly could. First, it's 100% free to download. It's 100% free to sign up, both for drivers and for passengers. It's 100% free for drivers to download their personal QR code.
When drivers actually receive tips on the system, there is going to be a small amount deducted from each tip. These are mostly fees charged by Braintree. Initially, 4.95% + $0.30 will need to be deducted from each tip that a driver receives.
But here's the interesting part. If we can process a certain amount of tips through this system every month, we can negotiate a lower processing fee with Braintree. The more money we are able to process, the lower the fees. So if the community pulls together and makes this work, i.e., if drivers put small signs with their QR codes in their cars, we can drive these charges down for everyone. This really is a community effort.

Are you really going to call this app Uber Hates Tips?

We'd like to, but, to be honest, probably not. We've got some more normal ideas for a name but if you think you've got a good one, please suggest it. We'd have a contest to name the app, but we know you'd all vote for Appy McAppface and we're not going there.

Risks and Challenges

Technically, there aren't any serious risks or challenges at all. All the functions we are implementing are straightforward. We are using Braintree for all the financial transactions as well as for secure storage of all sensitive financial information. We have already identified a design team to handle the actual coding.
To be honest, the only real risk in this project is, well, you. Not you personally, of course, we mean the community of Uber passengers and drivers. If the community wants this to work, it will absolutely work. But we all have to do our part by downloading the app -- which will be free, of course -- and, if you're a driver, by displaying your QR code in your car.

How Can I help?

First, of course, contribute! This is really a group effort.
But more importantly, participate! If you are a driver, sign up and put your QR code in your car. Get other drivers to put their QR code in their cars, too. Tell people about this campaign. Tweet about it. Write about it on Facebook. Tell your friends. This is basically free money, people! Your friends are gonna be mad at you if you don't tell them about it!
If you are a passenger, download the app. Tell your friends, too. When you take an Uber, be sure and brag to your friends that you know all about the sign in the car and that you were one of the people who helped create it.
Oh, and there is one other thing you can do: Follow us on Twitter!


Campaign Update: Great News!

Our campaign has generated a lot of interest in some very interesting places!
As we now have actual investors excited to back our project, it will no longer be necessary to rely on crowd funding to make this project a reality. After discussing it, we all feel that the right thing to do is to put all of our contributors first, thank them for their support and refund their contributions.
BUT
We will still be providing our contributors with the perks they were promised as our way of thanking them for standing in our corner. You all believe in this as much as we do and that means a lot to us.
So watch for the public rollout of the app which should be sometime in the next 90 days . . . and you can still say, "I did that!" because you did. None of this would have been possible without your enthusiasm and support
Thanks Again!
The Uber Hates Tips Team

story:
Since the emergence of "Smartphones", new possibilities have arisen to control electric and electronic appliances remotely. Until now, the industry has only provided complicated solutions that require the "switchboard" approach in order to be able to control objects from a "Smartphone" (e.g. home Wifi router, home automation switchboard).

We are now proud to introduce the "ON:NOT:ON" power strip, featuring individual control of each of its sockets via the "Smartphone". FULLY PLUG'N'PLAY

No APP needed – No Wifi router needed – No computer needed– No home automation switchboard needed.

 

How does it work?

It's very simple:

  • Users can connect any appliance* that they want to control to the power strip.
  • [ First time only] The user opens the browser's "Smartphone", select the WiFi signal generated by the power strip and introduce the password provided. This operation is automatic, but must be performed at least once.
  • A window will pop up on the browser displaying the 4 buttons list to control each of the 4 power strip sockets and a few further features.  From that moment, the Smartphone has become a remote control and the window will remain always open. It can be minimised and reopened at any time.

 [ Colour coded buttons for On/ Off check ]

 

Since the control is run from the Smartphone´s browser, there is no need for any additional software installation which makes it fully compatible with Android and iPhone. It is unbeatably simple, just....... connect ......and use. It´s that simple

Applications;

  • From the comfort of your sofa, you will be able to turn on and off any type of lights, fans, air conditioning*, turn the children's TV off at a certain time.
  • Switch on and off your coffee maker*, toaster*
  • Use it as a strong anti-theft measure simulating the presence of people at home. The power strip can activate its sockets randomly according to the pattern selected, e.g.:

                Turn on and off different lights at random.

                Turn radio on at a set volume level.

                ...and why not add some extra noise with a small vacuum cleaner*

  • Light set with smoke machine and stroboscope controlled from a Smartphone.

* check maximum power consumption allowed (1100W @ 110VAC, 2200W @ 220VAC)

What can I do if I need more sockets or if I want to control an object outside the house?

The power strip is totally compatible with X10 home automation elements.

If you want to remotely control your swimming pool pump or your garage gate, you can purchase an "X10" home automation module and insert it in one of your home or garage sockets to connect the element that you wish to control.

These elements will be controlled through additional buttons that will display in your Smartphone browser to turn on/off the X10 devices.

NO ELECTRICAL INSTALLATION REQUIRED as the ON:NOT:ON power strip will communicate with the X10 elements through the mains supply!

With up to 256 "X10" modules available to add, you can benefit from a complete home automation system without the need for a switchboard installation, and all controlled from your Smartphone for a very low price.

And for those who have an existing Wifi router at home, you can enjoy all available power strip functionalities from anywhere in the world (requires additional router settings and may vary depending on the Internet service)

Each of the ON:NOT:ON power strip  functions mentioned above has been tested for months and it is now time to move on to the production phase.

Your help via IndieGoGo is needed to reach a minimum 500 units, as this is the minimum amount to make this project feasible on the production level.

(Power strip available with U.S./UK/EU sockets)

Although in the video presentation is a prototype, this project is based on the fully OPEN SOURCE Arduino platform, so it can be modified and re-developed to meet each individual's needs. In fact we are anxious to discover what improvements can be added to the power strip. In case of any queries, please send us a message. We will be delighted to reply.

We also need your help via IndieGoGo to develop further Smartphone applications in the future to add extra features and to update the existing power strip functions.

Thanks for the music;

Wired Ant / CC BY 3.0
Darkroom / CC BY 3.0
grapes / CC BY 3.0
J.Lang / CC BY 3.0

 

 

VERSIÓN EN ESPAÑOL;

 

Desde la aparición de los “Smartphones” se ha planteado la posibilidad de controlar los objetos eléctricos-electrónicos a distancia. Hasta ahora la industria a dado soluciones complicadas necesitando añadir el concepto de centralita para poder controlar el objeto desde el “Smartphone” (p.ej. Router Wifi de la casa, centralita de domótica).

Ahora tengo el orgullo de presentaros el “ON:NOT:ON”, una regleta de enchufes con cada una de sus salidas controladas individualmente a través del “Smartphone”. TOTALMENTE PLUG’N’PLAY.

No necesita bajar APP – No necesita un router Wifi – No necesita ordenador – No necesita centralita de domótica.

 

¿ Como funciona ?

El funcionamiento es muy sencillo:

  • El usuario conecta los aparatos* que quiere controlar a la regleta.
  • [ Solo una vez ] El usuario abre el navegador de su “Smartphone”, selecciona la señal Wifi generada por la regleta e introduce la contraseña proporcionada. Esta operación es automática pero se tiene que realizar por lo menos una vez.
  • Aparece una ventana en el navegador con la lista de los 4 botones para controlar las 4 salidas de la regleta y algunas funciones más. A partir de ese momento el Smartphone se ha convertido en un mando a distancia ya que esta ventana puede quedar abierta permanentemente o reducirla para poder usarla en cualquier momento.

[ Comprobación del encendido/apagado gracias al cambio de colores de los botones ]

Dado que el control se hace mediante el navegador del Smartphone no es necesario instalar ningún programa. Eso le da compatibilidad total con Android e IPhone además de una simplicidad difícilmente superable ya que…se conecta…y se usa. Así de sencillo

 

Aplicaciones;

  • En el sofá de su salón podrá encender/apagar todo tipo de luces, ventiladores, aire acondicionado*, apagar la televisión a cierta hora (niños).
  • Encender/apagar cafetera*, tostadora*
  • Medida potente contra los robos mediante la simulación de presencia en su casa; la regleta puede activar de forma aleatoria sus salidas y según el padrón elegido por el usuario como podría ser:

               Distintas luces que se encienden y se apagan de forma aleatoria.

               Que se encienda la radio con un volumen elegido.

               ... y porque no un poco de ruido con un pequeño aspirador*

  • Juego de luces con maquina de humo y estroboscopio controlado por Smartphone

* Ver potencia máxima admitida (1100W @ 110VAC, 2200W @ 220VAC)

 

¿ Que hacer si necesito más enchufes o si quiero controlar un objeto fuera de casa ?

La regleta es totalmente compatible con los elementos X10 de domótica.

 

Si quiere controlar a distancia la bomba de la mini piscina, el portal de su casa, basta con comprar un modulo X10 de domótica y ponerlo a un enchufe de su casa o del garaje para conectar el elemento a controlar.

Se controlaran esos elementos gracias a unos botones adicionales que aparecen en el navegador del Smartphone para encender/apagar los dispositivos X10.

NO SE REQUIERE NINGUNA INSTALACIÓN ELECTRICA ya que la regleta ON:NOT:ON se comunica con los elementos X10 a través de la propia red eléctrica !

Teniendo en cuenta que se puede añadir hasta 256 módulos X10 se puede tener un sistema de domótica sin instalación de centralita y todo controlado por el Smartphone a un precio muy bajo.

No hace falta decir que a esta altura; el que disponga de un router Wifi en casa podría tener todas las funciones disponibles de la regleta en cualquier parte del mundo (requiere configuración del router y depende del servicio Internet)

Cada una de las funciones del ON:NOT:ON descrita con anterioridad ha sido probada durante meses y ha llegado el momento de pasar a la producción.

Necesito vuestra ayuda a través de IndieGoGo para llegar a un mínimo de 500 piezas, que es la cantidad minima para que el proyecto sea viable al nivel de producción.

(Regleta disponible para los enchufes de EEUU/UK/UE)

Aunque en el video de presentación se trata de un prototipo, el proyecto esta basado en la plataforma Arduino y es totalmente OPEN SOURCE, se puede modificar y reprogramar al gusto de cada uno. De hecho estamos ansiosos por conocer las mejoras que se pueden aportar a la regleta. Estamos a disposición para cualquier pregunta, basta con mandarnos un mensaje. Estaremos encantados de contestar.

Necesitamos también vuestra ayuda a través de IndieGoGo para que en el futuro se desarrolle alguna que otra aplicación para Smartphone para añadir funciones a la regleta y para actualizarla.

 

 

VERSION FRANÇAISE;

Depuis l’apparition des « Smartphones » il existe la possibilité de contrôler les objets électriques et électroniques à distance. Jusqu’à présent l’industrie a présenté des solutions compliquées nécessitant introduire le concept de centrale pour contrôler l’objet depuis le « Smartphone » (p.ex. Router Wifi de la maison, centrale de domotique).

Maintenant, j’ai le plaisir de vous présenter l’ « ON:NOT:ON », une multiprise dont chacune de ses sorties est contrôlée individuellement a travers le « Smartphone ».

Complètement Plug ‘n’ Play.

Pas besoin de descendre une APP – Pas besoin de router Wifi – Pas besoin d’ordinateur – Pas besoin de centrale de domotique.

 

Comment ça fonctionne ?

Le fonctionnement est très simple :

  • L’utilisateur connecte à la multiprise les appareils* qu’il désire contrôler.
  • [ Seulement une fois ] L’utilisateur ouvre le navigateur de son « Smartphone », sélectionne le signal Wifi généré par la multiprise et introduit le mot de passe fourni. Cette opération est automatique mais doit se réaliser au moins une fois.
  • Il apparaît une fenêtre dans le navigateur avec la liste des 4 boutons pour contrôler individuellement chacune des 4 sorties de la multiprise ainsi que quelques fonctions supplémentaires. A partir de cet instant, le Smartphone vient de se convertir en une télécommande à distance . La fenêtre avec les boutons peut rester ouverte ou être réduite pour pouvoir l’utiliser à n’importe quel moment.

[ Vérification de « allumer/éteindre » grâce au changement de couleurs des boutons ]

Étant donné que le contrôle se fait depuis le navigateur du Smartphone il n’est pas nécessaire d’installer une application. Cela permet la compatibilité totale avec Android et Iphone en plus d’une simplicité déconcertante en effet…..on le connecte……et on l’utilise. C’est aussi simple que ça !

 

Applications ;

  • Depuis le sofa de votre salon vous pourrez allumer/éteindre tout types de lumières, ventilateurs, air conditionné*, éteindre la télévision a certaines heures (enfants).
  • Allumer/éteindre cafetières*, grille-pain*
  • Puissante mesure anti-vol grâce à la fonction du simulateur de présence dans votre maison ; la multiprise peut activer de façon aléatoire ses sorties et suivant un modèle choisis par l’utilisateur comme cela pourrait être ;

                 Différentes lumières qui s’enclenchent de façon aléatoire.

                 Que la radio s’enclenche avec un volume déterminé.

                 …Et pourquoi pas un peu de bruit avec un petit aspirateur*

  • Jeux de lumières avec machine à fumée et stroboscope contrôlé par le Smartphone.

 * Ver puissance maximum acceptée (1100W @ 110VAC, 2200W @ 220VAC)

 

¿ Que faire si j’ai besoin de plus de prises ou si je veux contrôler un appareil en dehors de la maison ?

La multiprise est totalement compatible avec les éléments X10 de domotique.

 

Si vous voulez contrôler à distance une pompe de mini-piscine, le portail de la maison, il suffit d’acheter un module « X10 » de domotique et de le brancher à une prise de la maison ou du garage afin de contrôler l’appareil et cela en dehors de la couverture Wifi de la multiprise.

Ces éléments seront contrôlés grâce aux boutons supplémentaires qui apparaissent dans le navigateur du Smartphone pour allumer/éteindre les dispositifs X10.

IL N’EST DONC PAS NÉCESSAIRE DE RÉALISER UNE INSTALLATION ÉLECTRIQUE. En effet, la multiprise ON:NOT:ON  se communique avec les éléments X10 à travers du propre réseau électrique !

En tenant compte qu’il est possible de rajouter jusqu’à 256 modules X10 vous disposez donc d’un système de domotique sans installation de centrale et tout cela contrôlé par le Smartphone et cela à un prix très bas.

Pas besoin de dire à ce stade que celui qui dispose d’un routeur Wifi à la maison pourrait disposer de toutes les fonctions de la multiprise depuis n’importe quelle partie du monde (Configuration du routeur nécessaire et dépend du service internet)

Chacune des fonctions du ON:NOT:ON décrite précédemment a été testée pendants plusieurs mois et il est venu le moment de passer à la production.

J’ai besoin de votre aide a travers de IndieGoGo pour arriver à un minimum de 500 pièces qui est la quantité minimum pour que le projet soit viable au niveau de production.

(Multiprise disponible pour les prises de U.S./UK/Europe)

Même si dans le vidéo apparaît un prototype, le projet est basé sous la plateforme Arduino et est totalement OPEN SOURCE, il peut être modifié et reprogrammé au goût de chacun. En fait nous sommes anxieux  de connaître les améliorations qu’il est possible d’apporter à la multiprise. Nous sommes à disposition pour n’importe question, il suffit de nous envoyer un message. Nous serons enchantés de répondre.

Nous avons aussi besoin de votre aide à travers de IndieGoGo pour nous permettre de développer dans le futur l’une ou l’autre application pour Smartphone pour rajouter des fonctions à la multiprise et pour l’actualiser.

Ahora tengo el orgullo de presentaros el “ON:NOT:ON”, una regleta de enchufes con cada una de sus salidas controladas individualmente a través del “Smartphone”. TOTALMENTE PLUG’N’PLAY.

No necesita bajar APP – No necesita un router Wifi – No necesita ordenador – No necesita centralita de domótica.
 
¿ Como funciona ?
El funcionamiento es muy sencillo:

El usuario conecta los aparatos* que quiere controlar a la regleta.
[ Solo una vez ] El usuario abre el navegador de su “Smartphone”, selecciona la señal Wifi generada por la regleta e introduce la contraseña proporcionada. Esta operación es automática pero se tiene que realizar por lo menos una vez.
Aparece una ventana en el navegador con la lista de los 4 botones para controlar las 4 salidas de la regleta y algunas funciones más. A partir de ese momento el Smartphone se ha convertido en un mando a distancia ya que esta ventana puede quedar abierta permanentemente o reducirla para poder usarla en cualquier momento.
[ Comprobación del encendido/apagado gracias al cambio de colores de los botones ]
Dado que el control se hace mediante el navegador del Smartphone no es necesario instalar ningún programa. Eso le da compatibilidad total con Android e IPhone además de una simplicidad difícilmente superable ya que…se conecta…y se usa. Así de sencillo
 
Aplicaciones;

En el sofá de su salón podrá encender/apagar todo tipo de luces, ventiladores, aire acondicionado*, apagar la televisión a cierta hora (niños).
Encender/apagar cafetera*, tostadora*
Medida potente contra los robos mediante la simulación de presencia en su casa; la regleta puede activar de forma aleatoria sus salidas y según el padrón elegido por el usuario como podría ser:
               Distintas luces que se encienden y se apagan de forma aleatoria.
               Que se encienda la radio con un volumen elegido.
               ... y porque no un poco de ruido con un pequeño aspirador*

Juego de luces con maquina de humo y estroboscopio controlado por Smartphone
* Ver potencia máxima admitida (1100W @ 110VAC, 2200W @ 220VAC)
 
¿ Que hacer si necesito más enchufes o si quiero controlar un objeto fuera de casa ?
La regleta es totalmente compatible con los elementos X10 de domótica.
 
Si quiere controlar a distancia la bomba de la mini piscina, el portal de su casa, basta con comprar un modulo X10 de domótica y ponerlo a un enchufe de su casa o del garaje para conectar el elemento a controlar.

Se controlaran esos elementos gracias a unos botones adicionales que aparecen en el navegador del Smartphone para encender/apagar los dispositivos X10.

NO SE REQUIERE NINGUNA INSTALACIÓN ELECTRICA ya que la regleta ON:NOT:ON se comunica con los elementos X10 a través de la propia red eléctrica !
Teniendo en cuenta que se puede añadir hasta 256 módulos X10 se puede tener un sistema de domótica sin instalación de centralita y todo controlado por el Smartphone a un precio muy bajo.
No hace falta decir que a esta altura; el que disponga de un router Wifi en casa podría tener todas las funciones disponibles de la regleta en cualquier parte del mundo (requiere configuración del router y depende del servicio Internet)
Cada una de las funciones del ON:NOT:ON descrita con anterioridad ha sido probada durante meses y ha llegado el momento de pasar a la producción.
Necesito vuestra ayuda a través de IndieGoGo para llegar a un mínimo de 500 piezas, que es la cantidad minima para que el proyecto sea viable al nivel de producción.
(Regleta disponible para los enchufes de EEUU/UK/UE)
Aunque en el video de presentación se trata de un prototipo, el proyecto esta basado en la plataforma Arduino y es totalmente OPEN SOURCE, se puede modificar y reprogramar al gusto de cada uno. De hecho estamos ansiosos por conocer las mejoras que se pueden aportar a la regleta. Estamos a disposición para cualquier pregunta, basta con mandarnos un mensaje. Estaremos encantados de contestar.
Necesitamos también vuestra ayuda a través de IndieGoGo para que en el futuro se desarrolle alguna que otra aplicación para Smartphone para añadir funciones a la regleta y para actualizarla.
 
 
VERSION FRANÇAISE;
Depuis l’apparition des « Smartphones » il existe la possibilité de contrôler les objets électriques et électroniques à distance. Jusqu’à présent l’industrie a présenté des solutions compliquées nécessitant introduire le concept de centrale pour contrôler l’objet depuis le « Smartphone » (p.ex. Router Wifi de la maison, centrale de domotique).
Maintenant, j’ai le plaisir de vous présenter l’ « ON:NOT:ON », une multiprise dont chacune de ses sorties est contrôlée individuellement a travers le « Smartphone ».
Complètement Plug ‘n’ Play.

Pas besoin de descendre une APP – Pas besoin de router Wifi – Pas besoin d’ordinateur – Pas besoin de centrale de domotique.
 
Comment ça fonctionne ?
Le fonctionnement est très simple :

L’utilisateur connecte à la multiprise les appareils* qu’il désire contrôler.
[ Seulement une fois ] L’utilisateur ouvre le navigateur de son « Smartphone », sélectionne le signal Wifi généré par la multiprise et introduit le mot de passe fourni. Cette opération est automatique mais doit se réaliser au moins une fois.
Il apparaît une fenêtre dans le navigateur avec la liste des 4 boutons pour contrôler individuellement chacune des 4 sorties de la multiprise ainsi que quelques fonctions supplémentaires. A partir de cet instant, le Smartphone vient de se convertir en une télécommande à distance . La fenêtre avec les boutons peut rester ouverte ou être réduite pour pouvoir l’utiliser à n’importe quel moment.
[ Vérification de « allumer/éteindre » grâce au changement de couleurs des boutons ]
Étant donné que le contrôle se fait depuis le navigateur du Smartphone il n’est pas nécessaire d’installer une application. Cela permet la compatibilité totale avec Android et Iphone en plus d’une simplicité déconcertante en effet…..on le connecte……et on l’utilise. C’est aussi simple que ça !
 
Applications ;

Depuis le sofa de votre salon vous pourrez allumer/éteindre tout types de lumières, ventilateurs, air conditionné*, éteindre la télévision a certaines heures (enfants).
Allumer/éteindre cafetières*, grille-pain*
Puissante mesure anti-vol grâce à la fonction du simulateur de présence dans votre maison ; la multiprise peut activer de façon aléatoire ses sorties et suivant un modèle choisis par l’utilisateur comme cela pourrait être ;
                 Différentes lumières qui s’enclenchent de façon aléatoire.
                 Que la radio s’enclenche avec un volume déterminé.
                 …Et pourquoi pas un peu de bruit avec un petit aspirateur*

Jeux de lumières avec machine à fumée et stroboscope contrôlé par le Smartphone.
 * Ver puissance maximum acceptée (1100W @ 110VAC, 2200W @ 220VAC)
 
¿ Que faire si j’ai besoin de plus de prises ou si je veux contrôler un appareil en dehors de la maison ?
La multiprise est totalement compatible avec les éléments X10 de domotique.
 
Si vous voulez contrôler à distance une pompe de mini-piscine, le portail de la maison, il suffit d’acheter un module « X10 » de domotique et de le brancher à une prise de la maison ou du garage afin de contrôler l’appareil et cela en dehors de la couverture Wifi de la multiprise.

Ces éléments seront contrôlés grâce aux boutons supplémentaires qui apparaissent dans le navigateur du Smartphone pour allumer/éteindre les dispositifs X10.

IL N’EST DONC PAS NÉCESSAIRE DE RÉALISER UNE INSTALLATION ÉLECTRIQUE. En effet, la multiprise ON:NOT:ON  se communique avec les éléments X10 à travers du propre réseau électrique !
En tenant compte qu’il est possible de rajouter jusqu’à 256 modules X10 vous disposez donc d’un système de domotique sans installation de centrale et tout cela contrôlé par le Smartphone et cela à un prix très bas.
Pas besoin de dire à ce stade que celui qui dispose d’un routeur Wifi à la maison pourrait disposer de toutes les fonctions de la multiprise depuis n’importe quelle partie du monde (Configuration du routeur nécessaire et dépend du service internet)
Chacune des fonctions du ON:NOT:ON décrite précédemment a été testée pendants plusieurs mois et il est venu le moment de passer à la production.
J’ai besoin de votre aide a travers de IndieGoGo pour arriver à un minimum de 500 pièces qui est la quantité minimum pour que le projet soit viable au niveau de production.
(Multiprise disponible pour les prises de U.S./UK/Europe)
Même si dans le vidéo apparaît un prototype, le projet est basé sous la plateforme Arduino et est totalement OPEN SOURCE, il peut être modifié et reprogrammé au goût de chacun. En fait nous sommes anxieux  de connaître les améliorations qu’il est possible d’apporter à la multiprise. Nous sommes à disposition pour n’importe question, il suffit de nous envoyer un message. Nous serons enchantés de répondre.
Nous avons aussi besoin de votre aide à travers de IndieGoGo pour nous permettre de développer dans le futur l’une ou l’autre application pour Smartphone pour rajouter des fonctions à la multiprise et pour l’actualiser.

story:
PAUSE: The First Face Down Wireless Charger

Easily Disconnect From Your Phone

 

Pause is a Qi wireless phone charger made in exquisite oak wood that lets you charge your phone face down. Pause combines fast wireless charging while providing for more space and presence in your life. We invite you to put your phone on 'Pause'.

 

A Beautiful, Simple Solution For More Space In Your Life

 

It could be to be present for listening, reading, working, meditating, or just taking a moment for yourself. Pause lets you feel free from your phone and be in the moment.  It lets you disconnect from our hyper-connected lives. We want to make your days better and your connections stronger with Pause.

 

Charge face down, a simple life hack

 

No wireless charger exists today that lets you charge face down or is intended to help you create healthy boundaries with your phone use. It's really simple. Just slide your phone into your Pause charger and relax knowing it is safe, it is charging, and it is on pause.

 

All Other Wireless Chargers On The Market Charge Face Up

With wireless charging today, when you are trying to disconnect from your phone and avoid distracting notifications from your screen, you can't. When you want to sleep and not get woken up by your screen turning on, you can't. When you want to be reminded to not pickup your phone, you aren't. None of today's wireless chargers help you have more space and presence in your life. Pause does.

 

Create A Habit And Ritual Of Putting Your Phone On Pause 

In the entryway

Put your phone on Pause every time you get home. Just set it and forget it. Turn the rest of your house into a phone free space. 

In the kitchen

Charge your phones in the kitchen while you eat to have meaningful conversations around the dinner table, with your partner and your kids. 

In the bedroom

Charge your phone face down to avoid distractions and notifications and not be woken up. Or leave it on a dresser to have it far from you when you wake up. 

 

  

On your desk

Use Pause at your desk to focus and be more productive on deep work. Avoid getting distracted.

During meetings

Create great meeting hygiene by having your colleagues put their phones on Pause for better, more creative and more efficient meetings. 

 

How To Use Your Pause Charger

 

*No wireless charging phone? No worries! Will send you a wireless receiver for free to put between your phone and your phone case for it to work with Pause!

 

If your phone appears here, you need the free adapter:

Apple: iPhone 7, iPhone 7 Plus, iPhone SE, iPhone 6S, iPhone 6S Plus, iPhone 5S
Samsung: Galaxy S5, Galaxy S4, Galaxy S3, Galaxy Note 3, Galaxy Note 2
Microsoft: Lumia 930, Lumia 925, Lumia 830
Sony: Xperia Z3, Xperia Z2, Xperia Z

 

Make It Special With Custom Engraving

Get your Pause custom engraved! It's perfect for a gift for someone, for your company's logo, or just to have a cool design. When we are closer to shipping, we will reach out to ask you for a file for your custom engraving.

 

 

Pause is designed to be a beautiful object. Its most distinct features are the wood and hexagonal shape. They invite you to put your phone on Pause. The wood is to remind you of nature and being in the moment. When you reach for your phone, we want Pause to encourage you to be intentional with your decision. 

NOTE: The exact design of the charger and specifications are to change as we go through the Design for Manufacturing process in the coming months.

 

 

Phones with built-in Qi wireless charging

 

If your phone appears here, you just need to buy a wireless charger. If yours doesn't, we will send you a wireless receiver for free.The charger is powered via a USB-C input jack to help with fast charging. 

 

 

 

 


 

 

We started with the idea of helping people spend less time on their phones and more time being present. We took a user-center designed approach and spent hours researching, prototyping, and collecting data.  

We worked closely with Cite de L'Object Connecte in Angers, France to make our first working prototypes.

Our design and prototypes have been tested and proved. Now, we're about to begin the Design for Manufacturing process with our manufacturers to get to our first production run. We're perfecting the last details to bring Pause to you.

We are passionate about reminding people of nature and of not being stuck in a box on a screen. It's why we decided to make Pause out of sustainable wood. It's a reminder to be present, to be in the now, to appreciate what's in front of you and what you're feeling. It's a reminder to breathe. 

 

 

 

 

Hicham & Julian

 

Pause was created by Hicham Lahmamsi and Julian Nachtigal, who met at Imagination Machine, a Nantes, France-based accelerator, in 2017. They were deeply interested in the challenge and problem of smartphone dependence and use. It was an experience they both knew personally. It became clear that the way to disconnect more was by creating a physical ritual and habit that encouraged less phone and more life.

Pause was built to create phone free spaces and give you more presence by loosening the grip that our smartphones have on us. 

Our experience and partners make us feel confident we will deliver you a high-quality product.

 

 

Where do we ship?

 

We ship worldwide. All our prices include taxes, shipping is added when you checkout.

 

When do we start shipping?

 

We plan to ship the product in March 2019. Why so long? Most crowdfunding campaigns under-deliver on delivery timelines and we want to double and triple check our production level prototypes before our first run. We will keep you updated on our progress and the expected delivery date of your Pause wireless charger(s).

 

Why order now?

 

By backing us now, you'll get to own one of the first every Pause chargers and get exclusive access to special pricing, laser-engraving, and be valuable early adopters for Pause. You'll also be able to provide incredibly valuable feedback that will shape the future of Pause.

 

 

Thank you to everyone who has helped us on our journey over the last year. Pause has been a very humbling experience and we wouldn't be here without you. We're grateful for the time you spent with us, the knowledge and feedback you shared with us, and for just giving us a chance. A big thanks goes out to our partners: Imagination Machine, Cite de l'Objet Connecte Angers, Matiere Noire, LinetArt, MStream, and Hutisa. A special thanks goes out to you, our backers who believe in Pause and want to create a world with less phone and more life. 

 

 

We know there are huge challenges with hardware when it comes to manufacturing, production, and shipping. It is why we have allotted plenty of buffer in our planning so we can deliver on the estimated delivery date. Considering all the factors involved, it is possible that we may run into delays. While it is our first go around with hardware, we have spoken with many successful crowdfunding entrepreneurs and hardware manufacturers and feel that our estimates are realistic. We want to ensure your experience with Pause is the best one possible and will keep you updated along the way.

Questions about this project? Check out our FAQ below.

 

 

What is the Pause wireless charger?

Pause is the world's first face down wireless charger. It is a simple life hack to get off your phone, create phone free spaces, and build strong digital wellness habits and rituals.

 

Why should I use it?

The Pause charger is perfect for those wanting more space and presence in their life and looking for a great wireless phone charger.

 

What do I get with my order?

Your order will come with the quantity of Pause chargers your ordered and USB-C charging cables for each. The plug/power adapter is not included.

 

What plug do you recommend for Pause chargers?

We recommend a 9V 1.67A plug that is Qualcomm Certified at 2.0/3.0 level. This always the charger to work with your phones "fast charge" capability of either 7.5W (for iPhones) or 10W (many Androids). The USB-C cable we include is ideally suited for fast charging with the right plug. You can also use a 5V 2A plug, but it will charge your phone at 5W and be slower.

 

How does it work?

Pause works via induction charger. We use the Qi-technology standard, which is now the most commonly used wireless charging standard in smartphones. You just slide your phone in face down to charge. The LED light will indicate if the phone is charging or not. It is important your phone is properly aligned. 

 

What if my phone doesn't have wireless charging?

No worries! We can turn your phone into a wireless charging phone easily! We will send you a free Qi-wireless induction coil, that you will plug into your phones lightning, USB-C, or micro-USB port, and have wedged between your phone and your phone case. You can find out if your phone wirelessly charges here. 

 

Will Pause work if I use a phone case?

Yes, Pause should work with phone cases that 5mm thick or less. 

 

Who can use Pause?

Anyone!

 

What certifications does Pause have?

Pause is currently in the process of getting its CE, FCC, and [other] certifications.

 

When will I receive my order?

We plan to start shipping at the end of February 2019 and hope to have it to you by March 2019.

 

If I have any other questions, who can I contact?

Feel free to reach out to us at support@getpause.co.

 

Where can I buy more Pauses after the campaign?

You will be able to buy directly on our website, www.getpause.co, or InDemand via Indiegogo.

story:
Plug in to any outlet, and move it to any angle you need.

 

 

 

In layman’s terms: Working with the Assurance Program is like preparing for a test at school, but having all the questions and answers before taking the test.

 

 

We are pleased to say that we are able to keep manufacturing under our direct control. Instead of working with a molding company overseas to create the outer plastic parts that surround the internal components, we purchased our own injection molding machine. Avoiding the long lead time, high fees, and shipping costs for overseas plastics.

 

 

Risks and challenges

We will be responsive and transparent in every stage of our project, mostly including production, shipping and customer service. If we have any unexpected delay on delivery, we will inform you immediately.

story:
About Us

My husband and I are passionate about the outdoors and travel. Tony is a 200 nights a year business traveler and product development specialist. I am an artist and outdoor enthusiast that frequently finds my self miles from an outlet but still needing to keep my technology powered up.  Earlier this year we launched No Outlet No Problem power banks that we successfully funded on an alternative crowd funding site and have received rave reviews from our community of backers and customers with a 97.4% satisfaction rating from the survey we sent out!

(you can visit our website at http://www.nooutletnoproblem.com).

Project Summary

There are many different versions of the portable solar panel on the market, and we aren't claiming to have invented the underlying technology, only to have improved it while creating a nexus of price and performance that puts the technology within reach of the back-country adventurer, remote worker and preparedness community. We have also optimized the form to protect the devices you are charging from direct sun exposure (a major flaw in other designs).  We are also introducing the Round Trip multi-voltage 23,000mAh power bank that is compatible with our largest solar panel as a perk for the truly power hungry remote worker who needs to keep a laptop computer powered while working miles from wall power.

Goals and Perks 

We have finished all the development and raw materials sourcing.  We have created 5 of each model with our contract manufacturer for third party testing and received the results we were targeting, so we are ready for our first production run.  We need to raise a minimum of $25,000 to make that happen. We have included all the development details at the bottom of the page if you are interested in the roadmap we followed to bring these three products to you.

The Walkabout 7W (21" x 10" x 0.5" open / 10" x 7" x 1" closed)
This two cell solar panel weighs under 14oz (0.48kg) and has two 5V USB outputs that will charge at 500mA each.  21 x 10 x 0.5 inches when fully opened and only 10 x 7 x 1 inches when folded closed, it is perfect for keeping a battery topped off under light device loads.  We recommend plugging your device in one port and your Adventurer, Expedition or Destination into the other while you are out hiking, backpacking or sitting around your campsite. ( A Walkabout Outfitter pack is available if you don't have a power bank yet. )  Available in three colors: black, high-viz yellow and woodland camouflage. 

Walkabout Intro Video

The Outback 10W (27" x 10" x 0.5" open / 10" x 7" x 1.5" closed)
This three cell solar panel weighs just over 22oz (0.64kg) and has two 5V USB outputs that will charge at 800+mA each.  27 x 10 x 0.5 inches when fully opened and only 10 x 7 x 1.5 inches when folded closed.  It is ideal for keeping your device battery topped off under medium to heavy loads (GPS active).  We recommend plugging your device into one and your Adventurer, Expedition or Destination into the other while you'er hiking, backpacking or sitting around your campsite. Also ideal for RVs, back decks, the beach - you get the picture. (An Outback Outfitter pack is available if you don't have a power bank yet. )   Available in three colors: black, high-viz yellow and woodland camouflage. 

The Outback Video Intro

The Base Camp 25W (38" x 22" x 0.5" open / 11" x 7.5" x 2" closed)
This 8 cell solar panel is our largest and most powerful unit and is wired to provide enough voltage to charge a laptop computer (18V @ 1.4A) in strong direct sunlight. This unit weighs in at 3.3 pounds (1.6kg) and measures 38 x 22 x 0.5 inches when fully opened and only 11 x 7.5 x 2.0 inches when folded closed.  The Base Camp comes with 1x 5VDC USB @ 1.5A (max), 1x 12VDC @ 2.0A (max) and 18VDC 1.4A (max).  An assortment of charging tips for a wide variety of PC laptops are included - no Apple Magsafe connectors available but there are other options out on the internet that will work with the Base Camp system for Apple.  The Base Camp was able to provide a charge to both Compaq and Samsung laptops in strong full sun with the adaptors provided during our testing. From the 12VDC output you can charge auto accessories (DVD players GPS etc) and MS Surface Tablets.  

The Base Camp Video Intro

Please Note: It will not provide a charge to a laptop computer unless sunlight conditions are ideal and will charge at a significantly slower rate than a wall charger since it is only capable of providing 38% of the current a typical laptop wall charger would provide.

A Base Camp Outfitter pack featuring the BETA Round Trip is available that will act as a buffer, accepting the solar charge while distributing the internal battery to your laptop at AC wall adaptor rates.  

 

Summary Table

The Round Trip 23,000mAh Lithium Polymer Power Bank - BETA VERSION
The Round Trip is in Beta Testing and as a backer of this perk you will be come part of our pilot run and beta testing group.   Your input will be instrumental in the final production version of this product. This product is ready and safety agency approved, but a pilot run has not been completed and we have only limited tester input.  Please understand you are getting a BETA unit from the initial PILOT run of this product and it does not have all the asthetic finishing touches the retail version will have.  The case is an open mold and not our design, the internal electronics are the secret sauce and our proprietary Charge-Thru technology. 

The round trip features a multiple voltage output selector that allows the user to chose from 5V / 7.4V / 9V / 12V / 16V / 19V output through the high-quality multiple tip cable.  You simple hold down the power button and scroll through the options to select your voltage. You can create your own cable for specific applications by mixing and matching the supplied tips.  Output current is auto-sensed and supplied from 1A to a max of 4.2A to provide the same power as your OEM adaptor. (this buffer lets you extend your work time while used in conjunction with the Base Camp or can be used as a standalone backup for your laptop)

Tips that are supplied are for: Apple (old style magsafe), Sharp, IBM/Lenova, Asus, HP, DELL, Fujitsu, NEC and Sony.  Many other computers share these power charging tips. Your factory OEM cables will work as designed from the USB output for Retina and Lightning versions of Apple products. 

The Round Trip is charged from the suppled UL Listed 3A wall charger which can accept 110/240VAC at 50/60hz making it compatible world wide.  Charge time from wall power is 7-10 hours.   Charge time from the Base Camp solar panel is 15~23 hours.  It can take multiple days to charge the Round Trip from solar power depending on your sunlight conditions and usage.  The Round trip features our unique Charge-Thru(tm) technology and can be accepting a solar charge while powering a laptop or other DC powered device.  You can expect an additional 4-7 hours of additional run time from a typical laptop depending upon your usage. 

Out of the Lab: Real World Results

The way solar panels are measured creates some built in disappointment for most consumers and non-solar familiar folks. (We learned our lesson during out last campaign not to try to redefine how an established industry measures things!)  Testing labs simulate bright, cloudless noon day sun in a perfect orientation to the solar panel at 25c creating a maximum potential output.  They measure at one sun: 

  • Voc(V) open circuit voltage
  • Isc(A) short circuit current
  • Vmp(V) maximum power voltage
  • imp(A) maximum power current
  • Pmax(W) maximum power / rated power
  • Fill Factor - a power ratio 

In the real world you are going to have cloud cover and won't be around to direct the panel as the sun moves in many cases. So we have done some testing in a variety of real-world applications to give you an idea of how long something will take to charge - still the best indicator to the average person. 

The Walkabout averaged 380mA output from both USBs left in a single location during a lightly cloudy day.  If your phone has a 1500mAh battery it would have taken four hours to charge from empty at that rate.  With the dual outputs (one on phone/one on power bank) the Adventurer got a little better than a 50% charge in 10 hours. 

The Outback averaged closer to 700mA output from both USBs left in a single location during the same lightly cloudy day.  If your phone has a 1500mAh battery it would have taken just over 2 hours to charge from empty at that rate.  With the dual outputs (one on phone/one on power bank) the Adventurer got a full charge in under 9 hours, the Expedition got over a 65% charge in the same time period.

The Base Camp averaged over 1000mA output through the 5VDC USB and 1A at 18VDC from the laptop charging output during a lightly cloudy day (three day test).  Your 1500mAh battery phone would have taken less than an hour and a half to charge from empty (about the same as a stock wall charger) And an iPad Retina display unit would have charged 60-65%. An Expedition charged to almost 90% in a 10 hours test.   

There are so many variables with laptops and we have not been able to test with all the various manufacturers combinations.  Some laptops will not allow lower current charging such as the HP Elite Book which in our testing requires 3.5A @ 18V to charge.  We are comfortable with reporting that 1A @ 18VDC charging is supported, and works very well, but you need to look at your individual charging specification for your specific laptop to determine if lower current charging is supported we do not have a master list available of all the various combinations. 

Using the Round Trip power bank in conjunction with the Base Camp solar panel provides you the best of both worlds.  Acting as a buffer the Round Trip will power your laptop from the internal batteries while charging the internal batteries from the provided solar power.  This will extend your laptops battery by as much as 7 hours in a typical lightly cloudy day and leave you with enough extra power to charge a phone or GPS. 

Our Development Roadmap


We started early on with 9V mono-crystalline panels that we could readily source in Asia for all our first prototypes.  After extensive testing internally and submission to a third party testing house we determined they were not delivering the current and voltage we anticipated.  Our Two-cell "7-Watt" and "10-Watt" units came closest, but as we added more cells the miss-matches between cells added up and we saw efficiency drop and fall short of our targets. We switched to 6V cells for the higher capacity "25-Watt" unit and saw considerable increases in performance and cell mismatch had a smaller net impact.

After settling on a solar panel sources (3.5W @ 9VDC and 3.5W @ 6VDC) we set about designing a durable, foldable structure to house the assemblies. 

We visited with a number of factories that specialized in camping goods and found one that had experience sewing up foldable solar panels. We initially provided them the panels and an optimized USB charging circuit and they sewed us up some examples for test.  We knew that we needed a large mesh pocket on the back side of the panels to hold whatever we wanted to charge and to keep it out of direct sun. This was a major flaw we noted in existing products and one of the significant improvements in ours.  They either did not provide a pocket to hold a phone or battery or they put it right on the panel side of the unit in direct sunlight! Most electronics don't like elevated temperatures and exposurer to them will reduce a product's life and can even destroy it.  We think that this is a key feature that all companies should employ (and probably will a few days after our project goes live).  

We reviewed the materials that the factory had the best purchasing power for and ended up selecting 600D Polyester canvas for the enclosures.  It is rugged, available in a bunch of colors (we selected black, high-visibility yellow and woodland camouflage) and inexpensive to procure.  We sketched out the pouches and where we wanted them on the units and had some functional prototypes in just a few weeks.  We learned form our last project (on Kickstarter) that we needed to create a cohesive look and "brand" feel for these, and since we were doing all three at one time, it was easy to settle on stitching, embroidery, pocket locations and mounting methods. 

We decided on 550 chord for the lighter weight units.  You can clip it to a back pack or tie it over a tent with ease.  The 550 did not hold up on the heavier 25W unit so we went back to more traditional metal grommets.  We also decided to embroider our company name into each unit right on the front, so there was no mistaking whose solar charger you have! 

We enlisted a US company to provide third party testing over a wider range of temperatures as well.  Our first tests were very disappointing and resulted in additional tweaks until we hit the numbers we are providing you now. 

Production Plan

We have identified the factories to perform the final assembly and they require a 50% deposit to start work.  Once we are successfully funded we will wire them the deposit so they can procure the materials.  From our last experience with crowd funding, it takes 10 days to transfer the money to us and backers take a week to fill out the surveys for color choice, Indiegogo says expect 15 days.  We would expect to have all our purchase orders placed within 3 weeks of a successful close to this campaign. 

We are using our existing factory for the electronics, final packaging and test, all quoted lead-times for the raw solar panels have been taken into consideration.  We have an established track record here with an on-time reward delivery for our last project.  Our factory partner will be responsible for local market procurement, electronic assembly and test.

We will provide weekly updates during the production phase with photographs and adjustments if needed to the shipping schedule. 

Your Impact

We feel that solar chargers should not cost a fortune and that with careful design, creative manufacturing techniques and basic economies of scale we can create a price and performance point that puts solar charging within the reach of the average technology user.  Freeing up people to enjoy the places they want to be without being tethered to a wall outlet is our goal and your support is key.  You are the critical component to our success.  There is no way we a little husband and wife team can get the word out and have any hope of reaching our goal without people like you who are willing to give us a shot and trust us to deliver on our promise. We appreciate you and know you are the backbone of what we do and pledge not to let you down! Please share our project on Facebook and Twitter!  Let your friends know about us and together we can reach out goal and bring these to market!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our project with your community of friends and aquaintences!  Indiegogo has tons of easy to use and effective sharing tools!  We really appreciate you help in getting our Solar Chargers and Power Banks off the ground!

About Us
My husband and I are passionate about the outdoors and travel. Tony is a 200 nights a year business traveler and product development specialist. I am an artist and outdoor enthusiast that frequently finds my self miles from an outlet but still needing to keep my technology powered up.  Earlier this year we launched No Outlet No Problem power banks that we successfully funded on an alternative crowd funding site and have received rave reviews from our community of backers and customers with a 97.4% satisfaction rating from the survey we sent out!
(you can visit our website at http://www.nooutletnoproblem.com).
